subject: Re: [junit] a test pattern ?
msgSnippet: ... _JUnit Recipes_, recipe 4.8, provides a JUnit-based solution. For heavily data-driven tests, I recommend using Fit or FitNesse, rather than JUnit. FitNesse
messageBody:
Chris Downey wrote:
>
> Hello,
>
> I just finished writing a JUnit test. The test contains 5 values that
> are initialized in setup and used to configure the class being tested.
>
> For example:
>
> protected void setUp() throws Exception
> {
>
> priFacCost = 20789.0D;
> supFacCost = 4536.0D;
> supAdmPcnt = 5.7D;
> contPcnt = 5.0D;
> bidCostPcnt = 0.0D;
>
> pCostCalc = new ProjectCostCalculator(
> priFacCost,
> supFacCost,
> supAdmPcnt,
> contPcnt,
> bidCostPcnt
> );
> }
>
> This was great... until I realized that I need at least 5-10
> variations on the values in order to test what happens if a zero or a
> null is included in the ProjectCostCalculator parms. Any ideas on the
> best way to approach test design when you need to run it multiple
> times with different data configurations?
>
> The more I thought about this, the more I'm wondering if there is a
> known collection of JUnit test patterns. Any thoughts on this?

_JUnit Recipes_, recipe 4.8, provides a JUnit-based solution.

For heavily data-driven tests, I recommend using Fit or FitNesse, rather
than JUnit. FitNesse makes it easy to run the same test logic against n
rows of input and expected output.
--
